climbs.name: Barad-Dûr
climbs.fa: Matthew Peck, David MacFadden, Mar 7, '19. FFA Feb 1, 2022. Peck-MacFadden.

content.description:
The Dark Tower. Look for the always thin and frightening smear of ice above a short layback boulder problem. Topping this, head carefully up into a bowl (first bolt on the right) Pull through an overhanging ledge on to steep slab (crux) and then carefully tap your way to the top. The poor rock quality dictates a runout at the end but thin ice may be available.  11 bolts on the route but these tend to disappear in late season as ice thickens.  Keep an eye out right at the crux for a bolt just under the thin ice.  



Keep an eye out 20m south of Moria on the East side.  Due to the paucity of ice it's easy to miss.  Keep an eye out for the bolts. 

Sport rack plus thin ice screws.

A rad line.  Look for the iced up ramp on the West side immediately upon descending into the Tolkien area from the North.  Scratch your way up the ramp and traverse right onto a column to defeat the opening ice curtain.  You can backstep onto the back wall of the canyon at the crux usually to get your first good piece before pressing on to easier ground.  Delightfully technical, the opening runout is not for the faint of heart.  Bring multiple stubbies to protect the crux.



look left after descending into the squeeze canyon from the North. 

Thin Rack and Screamers.

Much harder early season. Climb out of the canyon on a verglas of ice or stem/traverse from the much fatter crucible side of the gorge if possible. Head up a low angle ramp on frozen moss/clumps of ice to a short but strenuous pillar (crux) and then up low angle steps to the trees. A good end of day exit from the Tolkien area in fat conditions. Fairly desperate in lean ice.



Directly across from Crucible in the Tolkien Area. In early season climb the delicate smear of ice (!) on the west wall of the canyon, or later in the year traverse the growing ice from the East (crucible) side for a much easier and safer start.

Thin ice rack and runners.

Look up to see the left leaning corner of Ramble On Rock finish above and climb a low angle ice ramp through some scrappy rock to the ramble on ledge. A more convenient way to reach the route, but not very satisfying.



Best accessed by the hiking trail bridge, this climb starts on the east bank at the very bottom of the crag. 

Thin ice rack

Older and fouler than Crucible.  The beautiful Moria starts with a steeper bit of dry tooling with a thin coating of ice, and has the same cool backstep to get your first screw in.  The ice afterwards is steeper than Crucible, especially to the right.  Fight on to the belay. 



10-15 M further south from Crucible, on the East Side. 

Thin Ice Rack and Screamers.

Climb a thin slab or use a large dead tree and continue upwards, heading for a short, slender pillar above.  It's often advisable to sling the base of the pillar, as this is likely your first decent protection in a while, and the crux is above. 



Before entering the Tolkien area from the North, look up to the East (on the third day.....) you'll see a lonely, short pillar above a long thin slab. 

Thin ice rack

Climb the thin flow of ice at the cavern mouth past hiking debris to a ledge.  From here either continue along the ledge past a large Spruce and up a short ice wall to belay above or head straight up a dry corner on bolts (cams for the first moves, .5-2 until final bolts installed). Ring anchor at top.  This route is often used to access the Tolkien area anchors.



Before exiting the south entrance of the Tolkien area, look to the East for a small bulge of ice headed up through the trees.  Hit it. 

Standard Ice Rack and draws.  Cams may be required.

climbs.name: You can have my Sword, and my Bow
climbs.fa: Matthew Peck, Kara Vogler, Bader Kanawati, Jan 25, '20

content.description:
A Real Stinker.  This climb is what can be necessary if the ice bridge into the Tolkien area fails.  Climb up to the West side on iced (hopefully) moss to a small ledge, traverse North and use a sapling to tension descend to firmer ground.  Really only labelled as a fun reminder of bad decisions. 



If you blow the bridge, you'll find out where it is. 

Brown pants.

An almost unreal box canyon, that at times closes in overhead. Ice in this area is more sparse and the climbs are techy, thin and pumpy. Extreme care should be taken while traversing into the area from the north, as access is always dicey, depending on a thin ice-bridge and good balance. Send your small climbers in first and be prepared to fish them out of the water. Getting down into this part of the gully is more climbing than walking.

Rockfall has been noticed in the fall of 2020 in this area. Several large chock-stones with loose debris on top are still held in place overhead, and a number of hangfires (partly fallen dead trees) also remain suspended above. Though more stable in the winter, care should be taken on warm days especially. Hikers also clamber into this part of the crag from the Wards Falls hiking trail when the lower falls ice up. Hikers are often ignorant of the dangers of approaching an ice climb, and will certainly not have helmets or crampons to keep them safe. Be sure to kindly illustrate the dangers of spectating if they approach.
